qas.question: Who noticed that sleepiness increases and decreases in a 24 hour period?
Who showed the animals could maintain activity in the absence of light and temperature changes?
What animals rhythmic feeding times were studied in the early 20th century ?
What gene did Konopka and Benzer map in the early 1970 s?
What mutation did Takahashi discover in 1994?
Who observed that sleepiness remained steady over twenty-four hour period?

plausible_answers.text: animals are capable of maintaining 24-hour activity patterns in the absence of external cues

qas.question: What did Patrick and Gilbert show in 1918?
What was noticed in the rhythmic feeding time of birds in the early twentieth century?
What did Ingeborg Beling and Oskar Wahl isolate in the early 1970s?

context: In 1896, <a0_0><b5_0>Patrick and Gilbert<b5_0/><a0_0/> observed that during a prolonged period of sleep deprivation, sleepiness increases and decreases with a period of approximately 24 hours. In 1918, <a1_0>J.S. Szymanski<a1_0/> showed that <b6_0>animals are capable of maintaining 24-hour activity patterns in the absence of external cues<b6_0/> such as light and changes in temperature. In the early 20th century, <b7_0>circadian rhythms<b7_0/> were noticed in the rhythmic feeding times of <a2_0>bees<a2_0/>. Extensive experiments were done by Auguste Forel, Ingeborg Beling, and Oskar Wahl to see whether this rhythm was due to an endogenous clock.[citation needed] Ron Konopka and Seymour Benzer isolated the <b8_0>first clock mutant in Drosophila<b8_0/> in the early 1970s and mapped the <a3_0>"period"<a3_0/> gene, the first discovered genetic determinant of behavioral rhythmicity. Joseph Takahashi discovered the first mammalian <a4_0>circadian clock<a4_0/> mutation (clockΔ19) using mice in 1994. However, recent studies show that deletion of clock does not lead to a behavioral phenotype (the animals still have normal circadian rhythms), which questions its importance in rhythm generation.
